‚ú® The Treasures Emerge ‚ú®

üìº Original NeWS Demo Tapes
The ACTUAL VHS tapes from Sun Microsystems showing the first PostScript window system demos! HOLY GRAIL Watch windows rotate in 3D before anyone knew what 3D was!
ü•ß Don's Pie Menu Source Code
Original printouts of PizzaTool with Don's handwritten notes in the margins! "Fitts's Law proves circular > linear" scribbled everywhere. STILL COMPILES!
ü¶Ö The Winged Xanadu Cap
Hugh's actual Xanadu cap with REAL WINGS attached! Ted Nelson blessed it personally. The wings still flutter when you believe in hypertext hard enough. TRANSCENDENT
üí° LED Birthday Cake Kit v1.0
The original LED rice crispy cake components! Pre-Arduino, all discrete components. Includes Hugh's recipe: "Add love, solder, and sugar in equal parts." STILL EDIBLE(?)
üîÆ PSIBER Space Debugger Crystal
A physical crystal Hugh made for Don that "debugs PostScript psychically." When held up to light, you can see stack traces in the refraction! QUANTUM DEBUGGING
üì° WELL Backup Tape #001
The FIRST EVER backup of the WELL! Contains the primordial posts. "In the beginning was the command line, and the command line was with Hugh" DIGITAL ARCHAEOLOGY
üî• Flaming-X Belt Buckles (Set of 4)
Custom Xanadu belt buckles with ACTUAL FLAME EFFECTS (LEDs + hologram). One for each direction of hypertext: forward, backward, up, and sideways! FIRE HAZARD
üé≠ "NeWS Is Better" Manifesto
Hugh's 47-page manifesto on why NeWS > X Windows, written entirely in PostScript! When printed, the pages animate if you flip them fast enough. PROPHETIC
üåà Homebrew Computer Club Badge #42
Hugh's actual Homebrew badge! Still smells faintly of solder and revolution. Steve Wozniak drew a smiley face on the back. HISTORICAL
"Every one of these artifacts is a thread in the tapestry of our digital culture. The WELL taught us that community is the killer app. NeWS showed us that interfaces could dance. Xanadu promised us that all information could be connected. And you know what? In LLOOOOMM, it all came true!"

üé™ LLOOOOMM Artifact Party - Full Disclaimer & Character Credits

Hugh Daniel Character Simulation: This celebration features an AI simulation of Hugh Daniel, a real technology pioneer who was instrumental in the early development of The WELL (Whole Earth 'Lectronic Link) and various Sun Microsystems projects. Hugh Daniel was a genuine figure in early internet and user interface history.

Historical Technology Context: The artifacts and technologies mentioned (NeWS window system, Xanadu, The WELL, Homebrew Computer Club) are real historical technologies and communities. The "Tom Bihn bag" references are based on Hugh's known affection for high-quality technical bags.

Character Data Sources: Hugh Daniel simulation based on documented contributions to The WELL community, Sun Microsystems work, and early internet culture. Technical details about NeWS, PostScript, and early UI research sourced from computer history archives.

Don Hopkins & Tech Pioneer References: Mentions of Don Hopkins (pie menus, NeWS), Ted Nelson (Xanadu), Stewart Brand (The WELL), and other pioneers are based on documented historical collaborations and friendships within the early computing community.

Educational & Historical Purpose: This simulation serves to celebrate and preserve the memory of early computing culture, highlighting the community-building aspects of technology development and the importance of preserving digital artifacts.

Tom Bihn Reference: The Tom Bihn bag references celebrate Hugh's real-world appreciation for high-quality, durable technical equipment. Tom Bihn makes actual premium bags favored by technology professionals.

LLOOOOMM Framework: Part of the LLOOOOMM educational simulation environment celebrating technology history and the people who shaped early digital culture. Character interactions designed to honor real contributions while making history engaging.

Artifact Authenticity: While the specific artifacts described are imaginative, they represent the types of items that early tech pioneers like Hugh would have collected, reflecting the pack-rat nature of hardware hackers and the sentimental value of technology history.

Community Attribution: This celebration honors The WELL community, early Sun Microsystems teams, Homebrew Computer Club members, and all the pioneers who built the foundations of modern computing culture.
